What medicine's best? Counsel, and that I'll take.

div.stage: Enter Barnaby, Raph, and Hugh.

lg.l: Come, come, an you be men, make haste:
You 'tis a hanging matter; the emperor and all the prisoners
Are gone by already.

sp.speaker: Râ—ph..
sp.p: Stay, stay, here's our fellow Crispin, let's take him with us. Wilt thou go along Crispin?

lg.l: Whither should I go? prithee tell me,
What make you all at Canterbury?
Not to buy the cat a bell Crispin, but to make loiter-pins.
For this day boy, we have made holy at Feversham,
Shut up shop, thrown by our shoe-thread, and washed our faces:
And now my master and dame, and all of us are come
To see the emperor, and the Christians that must die today.
They say there's a fine young Queen amongst them:
Prithee go along with us.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: In sadness I cannot.

lg.l: In madness now I care not:
for our shoes are made of running leather,
And therefore we'll gallop no man knows whither.
Farewell Crispin: shalt see my dame come chasting this away anon,
'Cause we ran away from her: come fellow Hugh,
Thou art so sad now, I prithee be merry. Exit Barnaby and Raph.
I'll follow straight, although to meet my ruin;
The Princess Winifred is doomed to die,
And I in death will bear her company. Exit.
Misery of times when Kings do kill,
Not armed by law to do it, but by will.
From these deep woes that my poor country bears
Heaven save the Queen my mother, fates are just,
And till the thread be spun, none turn to dust.

div.stage: Enter the shoemaker's wife sweating.

lg.l: Fie, fie, fie;
Heaven for thy pity how am I used today!
Here be youths indeed to run away, and leave me in this order.
Do I keep one, two, three, four, and five journeymen,
Besides prentices, uprising and down-lying,
And do they all bob me of this fashion?
How now, art thou there Crispin? that's well:
Did you see your fellows?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Yes my good dame; they are all before you.

lg.l: Then I'll have you before me too, but not so far as they are:
Fie, fie, see how I sweat with following them:
Come sir, though they gave me the slip, you'll not serve me so I hope.
Go before, and man me.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: O my good dame!

lg.l: How now Crispin, what's the matter boy?
Why are so many chancery bills drawn in your face?
Now, where sits the wind that you blow so?
What ailest thou?
I have ever found you a kind loving dame, nay, a good mother
Both to myself, and my poor brother Crispianus.
Bless him good heaven, upon what ground soe'er he tread:
he was an honest fellow, and a good servant,
And so he shall find, if e'er he come
From the wars again.
O my good dame, I to your ears must now unlock
A secret, which, if ere you blab abroad â€”
Never by my holy dame;
Yet I have much ado to keep my own secrets,
But I'll keep thine I'll warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: Nay look dame, my life and death lies on it.

lg.l: Let what will lie on't,
It shall ne'er be talked of by me.
I'll thank ye then;
This it is, but you will say nothing?

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.l: Dost think I am a woman or a beast?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Nor be angry with me?

lg.l: Here's ado indeed,
Thou hast not got a wench with child haste?
You have found my grief,
Good dame, indeed I have.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.l: Out upon thee villain.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Nay good dame.

lg.l: Hence you whoremaster knave,
God's my passion, got a wench with child,
Thou naughty pack thou hast undone thyself for ever:
Precious coals, you are a fine youth indeed,
Can you cut out no shoes but of duck's leather,
With a wanion? has your master so little doings,
Your tools must be working abroad in a foreigner's shop?
Sweet dame, you swore
You would say nothing.
Nothing, hang thee villain, I'll cry it at the market cross:
I'faith, is your awl so free for smock-leather?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: Good dame.

lg.l: By these ten fingers I'll double thy years for't:
O that I knew the quean, I'd slit her nose,
And tear her eyes out of her head i'faith.

div.stage: Enter shoemaker.

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.l: How now, what's the matter that it thunders so?

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: O, you are as good a master too o'th to the side: you look to your prentices well; one of your men has been at green-goose fair; but he shall pay for the sauce I'll warrant him.

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.l: What fair? what sauce, goody gandergoose?

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis no matter, as he likes this, let him dance the shaking of the sheets another time.

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.l: What sheets dame Guinevere? what dance I pray ye?

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.l: Marry uptails all: do you smell me now?

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.l: I smell an ass head of your own: what's all this trow?

lg.l: Pardon me sir.
Unless you stand my friend,
Alas I am but dead.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: Dead, hang ye rascal, hang ye; you were quick enough when you laid your whore on her back, to take measure of her new shoes: would you think it husband, this young knave has got a wench with child.

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.p: Hoyda, and is this the shaking of the sheets you talk of, goodwife Snipper Snapper: 'sfoot I like him the better fort: he is of your husband's trade, you old whore, and he has mettle in him: dost scold for that, hold your tongue with a pox.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.l: Ay, ay, one whoremaster will take part with another still.

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.l: Peace Walflit, leave gaping.
sp.p: A wench with child? 'sfoot in my my capering days I have done as much myself Sis.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.l: Ay, beshrew your heart for your labour.

lg.l: Peace Sisley, I shall sow up your lips else;
Let me talk with my prentice:
Hast got a maid with child sayest?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: A maid, marry hang her whore.

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.p: Yet again, keep your clack, I'll slit your tongue else. Speak my young cock-sparrow, what merry wagtail hast thou been billing with?

lg.l: O sir, if any but my dame and you should know it,
I were lost for ever.

sp.speaker: Shâ—o.
sp.p: Mum, mum for my part boy; and you Margery Magpie, keep your tongue from chattering, or by the marry maskins I'll tickle your gaskins: come, say, what didapper was't?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: The emperor's daughter sir.

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.l: Who, the Princess?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Out upon thee traitor.

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.p: 'Sfoot will bow-bell never leave ringing? will the perpetual motion of your old chaps never leave sounding? I shall beat your clapper out anon for't: ah sirrah, go too boy, no court-mustard serve your turn but the emperor's daughter? This is fine i'faith.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: He'll smoke for't I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.p: Why Wiperginie, prating still I say? thou'st drawn on her shoe handsomely by the mass: prithee tell me, how couldst thou being but a poor shoemaker, climb up to a court-bed-sted?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: He'll climb to the gallows for't.

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.l: Why Knipperdolin, is the devil in thee?

lg.l: I have climbed farther sir; she's now my wife,
And I have married her.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Hoyda.

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.l: Hush madge owlet, leave hollowing.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: That very day my brother was pressed forth â€”

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: You pressed her at night, did you?

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.l: Grunting still you sow-gelder?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Thou art a coxcomb and a clapperdudgeon: dost thou see now, I was never so called in my life as thou callest me. Thou mayst be ashamed on't: this 'tis to let thy prentices have their swing, and lie out at nights thus.

lg.l: Sweet pigsney, let me entreat thy patience:
Alas poor youth, we must needs help him.
Why I commend him that he shoots at the fairest mark:
What an excellent show an emperor's daughter will make in a
Shoemaker's shop!
She'll spin a fair thread I warrant you:
How will he maintain her trow ye?
She knew my fortunes e'er she married me,
And now yourselves shall know them:
I and my brother that thus have served you like prentices,
Are princes both, and sons to Alured, late King of Britain.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: How! my right worshipful prentice! Stands bare

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Ha, is he a King's son husband?

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.l: Make curtsy to your man you whore.

lg.l: The emperor Maximinus slew my father,
And put the Queen my mother into prison:
What mean you gentle master, pray be covered.
No by my faith sir,
You are a better man than the master of my company.
And seeing all my hopes lie dead save in herself,
I loved, revealed myself, and married her;
Yet I entreat you both â€” nay gentle master,
I am your prentice still, pray stand not bare.

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.p: Well, well, for this once I will boy; now you old jigambob, you never had two such men to man you.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Nay truly husband, I ever thought they were some worshipful man's sons, they were such mannerly boys still.

lg.l: All I entreat of you, is some advice
To get my fair Leodice from court, and then some secret place
Where she might be in safety till her sweet delivery,
And then I'll dare misfortune.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Blessing of thy heart, I like thee well thou'st such a care of thy wife: therefore if thou couldst but steal her from the court, and bring her hither, she should lie in, and be brought to bed at my house â–ª and nobody know it I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.l: I marry Tib-tattle basket, how should we do that wench?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: That's all my care indeed, to steal her thence.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Come, come, leave it to me boy, I see, a woman's wit must help at a pinch still boy: mark this device, and if you like it, do it, and thus it is: soon at night thou shalt hire some friend to fire a tree upon the coast at Dover, as near the beacons as can be possible, by which means the men that watch the other beacons, seeing that in flames, and supposing some enemy landed, will presently fire all the rest, and so on a sudden set both court, city, and country, and all in an uproar, in which time if you and she cannot bestir your stumps, and run both away, would you were whipped i'faith.

lg.l: An excellent pate to trouble the whole commonalty;
The plot is good i'faith boy.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: I like it well, and will acquaint the Princess with it.

div.stage: Enter Barnaby and Raph crying.

lg.l: O master and dame, dame and master;
Oh lamentable day! now or never.

sp.speaker: Shâ—o.
sp.l: How now knaves, toll one bell at once, and leave jangling.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: O pitiful master, intolerable dame, I am the fore-bell, and h'as rung all in many a time and often with you dame: but now I must wring out mine own eyes in tears, in dolour, and most doleful knells: my fellow Hugh is taken, and condemned like a christian.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: O horrible!

lg.l: Peace bagpipe: my man Hugh condemned,
How comes that?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: O master, your man Hugh is not the man you took him for; not plain Hugh, but sir Hugh, a knight of fame.

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.l: How? A knight of the worshipful company of the cordwainers?

lg.l: Nay, by st. Davie, he's more, he's a Welsh prince,
And son to the King of Powes in South Wales,
Though he but a shoemaker here.
Passion of me, what a brood of princes have I brought up!
And why is my right honourable servant to be put to death?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: As we were going to see the Christians, he spied his old love Queen Winifred amongst them, and at the very sight he looked as green as a leek, and so rushed in amongst them; took the lady by the lily-white hand, railed on the Roman gods, defied the emperor, and swore he would die if she did.

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.l: Is there no help to save him?

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: None in the world, except he leave to be a christian.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: 'Tis true sir, all the sergeants and officers that came to arrest him, pitying his case, persuaded him to be no good christian, as they were: then there was a broker said he would lay his soul to pawn, he could not prosper if he were a christian; nay, the jailor cries out on him, and says, if he continue a christian, he'll use him like a dog.

lg.l: Alack the day;
I'm sorry for my honourable boot hailer:
Go and comfort him; I'll see him anon tell him.
Nay, stay sweet master,
'Twas never seen that a shoemaker and his men
Were base bassilomions, but true bonus socius,
Up see freeze, though we cannot get him from prison,
I'll sell my coat from my back, ere a shoemaker
Shall want: let us show ourselves cavaliers
Or cobblers: come every man his twelvepence
A piece to drink with him in prison.
A good motion: boon boys, fine knaves;
I like you well when you hang together:
Hold my brave journeymen,
There's a double share for me.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: And mine with all my heart i'faith.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.l: And cause he's a knight, thou shalt have my shilling too.

lg.l: I thank you dame:
Nay, we'll never leave a brother of our
Company, as long as flesh and bones
Will hang together.
Away boys, go you before;
Joan jumble breech your dame and I will follow,
Cherish him up, tell him he shall not want;
He lives not in the world could ever say,
A shoemaker from his friend did flinch away. Exeunt.

div.stage: Flourish: enter Maximinus, Bassianus, Lutius, officers; Albon and Amphiabel in their shirts, as from torments.

lg.l: Resolve me yet, you stubborn Christians,
Cannot the several tortures which we do inflict,
Yet melt the iron of your hardened hearts,
To make you bow unto our Roman gods?
Speak, will you obey our hest?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: None but the hests of heaven.

lg.l: A thousand deaths have not the bitter stings
As are the pains we have felt in torturing;
Yet tyrant we'll endure ten thousand more,
And laugh in death's face, ere we our faiths give o'er.
Renowned Albon, on thy head I'll set
A crown of gold.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: To make me heaven forget: never.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Never.

lg.l: Let me yet win thee foolish man:
Remember what honours we, and Dioclesian
Heaped upon thee: giving thee the style
Britain's stewardship,
The prince of knights,
Lord of Varlome.
And in thy racks, thy irons, gibbets, and thy wheel,
Do I more honour, and more comfort feel,
Than all those painted smokes by thee bestowed
Of me: my country may thus much boast: Albon
Stood firm and fixed, in spite of tyrant's wrath,
Britain's first martyr for the Christian faith.
But not the last:
For to thy scorn I'll add millions of
Christian flames, to death and tortures.

sp.speaker: Lut.
sp.l: Dispatch these first.

lg.l: I will drag them hence in chains to
Helnurst hill, three miles from Verolome,
Where Albon's lord, there after blows,
And spiteful buffetings, for honour of his
Knighthood, once held the chief,
He shall have a knight to be his headsman.
That stroke shall well be given,
That makes room for a soul to fly to heaven.
This fiend Amphiabel,
From whose damned teat he sucked this poison,
Shall there be bound by a fixed stake,
To which nailed fast, the navel of his belly
Being opened, then with your sword prick him,
and force him run about like a wheel,
Till he has spun his guts out: and that dispatched,
Saw off his traitorous head.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Caesar in greater triumph ne'er was led.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Away with them; Albon's the first shall die:

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Thou honour'st me amid thy tyranny: come on dear friend,

lg.l: Eternity protect us to our end:
Fight nobly then.
To my latest breath:
I go to a wedding (Friend) and not to death.
Go drag 'em hence; this day we'll
Quaff the blood of Christians: call forth more:
So perish all will not our gods adore.

div.stage: Enter Hugh, Winifred, and shoemakers.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Nay fellow Hugh, or noble sir Hugh, remember 'tis not every man's case to die a christian; prithee leave it then, and save thy life; the Roman gods are as good gods as e'er trod on a shoe of leather: and therefore sweet Hugh we may get their custom, and bring 'em to our shop, and so we shall be shoemakers to the gods.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.l: You trouble me, I pray leave.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Leave thee, not as long as thou livest i'faith.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: What are all these?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Men that respect a christian no more than you do, sir you need not fear, there's not a good christian among us.

lg.l: Honest fellows:
Back, and give the prisoner's room.
Come my constant friend:
Noble sir Hugh at last farewell join hands
We never shall touch one another more,
When these we sever; thou long hast
Loved me; truer never was found,
That both in life and death keeps faith so sound:
All that my love can give thee for thy pains
I'll marry thee, but death must bid the banes:
Never to wedding was such honour given,
our wedding dinner must be kept in heaven.
At which angels shall wait:
Saints be our guests, our souls the wedding couple,
And the feast joy and eternity; our bridal room
The hall of heaven, where hand in hand we'll come,
Martyrs to dance a measure, which begins
Unto the music of the cherubins.
Mean time, even here you both shall dance with death;
Yet if our god's you'll serve, prolong your breath.
'Tis life we seek to lose; tyrant strike home,
They are but walls of clay which thou beast down.
Call a hangman, flay that
Villain straight, and tear that woman's
Flesh with burning pincers.
We both are ready sir,
Yet hear me Maximinus: by all the rites
Of honour I conjure thee, in law of womanhood,
Let not my body be a villain's prey;
But since I am a Queen and spotless virgin,
Let me choose my death.
Because thou once wert daughter to a King
Enjoy thy wish, so death may forth with strike,
Meet him in any shape thou best shall like.
Be sure it shall:
Be thou the chief mourner at my funeral.
My earthly love farewell; thy cheek I'll kiss,
We'll meet anon within the land of bliss:
Follow my footsteps thou shalt soon be there:
Courage good heart, to die I cannot fear.
I'll be the first, and teach thee how to die,
Leading the way to sweet felicity.
Come tyrants launch my arm, to death I'll bleed,
Sweet blood was shed for me, and mine I'll shed.
Dispatch and launch her arm, but save the blood
The which this day to holy Jupiter I'll sacrifice.
My dearest friend farewell,
In one house shortly we'll for ever dwell.
The storm of death now comes,
Bear up brave sail.
I feel no storm; but oven the merriest gale
That ever life was driven with: o how sweet a
Dream methinks I now am in;
Angels do run to meet and welcome
Me unto the land of bliss,
Singing I have spun a golden thread

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.l: That thread of gold weave still.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: I do; farewell: make haste to meet â€”Dies.

lg.l: In faith I will, in a whole camp of martyrs; blessed fate
She's gone for ever to an angel's state.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Dispatch him; and drag her body hence.

lg.l: 'Tis sister to the saints; o give it reverence.
Why do I linger here, my love being gone?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: A right shoemaker, he loves a woman.

lg.l: Merciful tyrant set me on death's wings,
That I may bear a part where my love sings
Eternal hymns of joy; blessed love I come, as soon
As I can set forth out of this house of earth and clay:
When shall this stroke be given,
That I may mount and meet my love in heaven?
Flay him alive:
Yet stay, because you are so lovesick, we'll give
You a drink to cure it: pour into a cup
His sweetheart's blood, and give it us.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.l: 'Tis precious wine, holy, and good.

lg.l: And you shall quaff your fill:
So, put in poison, spice it well;
There drink thy last, and sink with her to hell.
O let me kiss this heavenly cup of all my happiness:
Dear love to thy blessed souls eternal goodness,
I drink this health, filled to th' brim:
Two hearts did never so in one stream swim,
As thine and mine shall now; and though thy blood
Be poisoned, this our loves keeps firm and good.
My country men and fellow shoemakers,
as of my best of friends I take my leave:
We many times together have drunk healths,
But none like this: yet I'll begin to you all;
But here you shall not pledge me.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Yes, and 'twere aquavitae we would pledge thee.

lg.l: The love which I so found in you,
Even in my latest hour, I'll not forget,
But to you all begin my lasting love,
Never did fair society of men more please me: you are a trade
Of fellowships best mixture, nobly made.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: We are shoemakers, and so.

lg.l: My being amongst you, thus shall you prefer,
To say a prince was once a shoemaker.
For which you now shall raise your skill aloft,
And be called gentlemen of the gentle craft.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: O noble sir, Hugh.

lg.l: Could I give Indian mines, they all were yours;
But I have naught to give, nor ought to take,
But this my farewell; therefore for my sake,
When death has seized my flesh,
Take you my bones, which I bequeath
Amongst you to be buried.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Take no care for thy winding sheet, sweet Hugh, for never was gentleman of the gentle craft so buried as thou shouldst be, if thou hadst drunk thy last.

lg.l: Now trouble me no more:
Upon this stage of death I set my foot to all farewell,
Angels shall clap their wings to ring my knell,
And bid me welcome to the land of rest,
Where my immortal love lives ever blessed:
A health dear soul I'll drink to thee: so, so,
How soon he fades, that now so fresh did grow!
Fly up my soul to heaven, my sins sink to the earth;
Thus do I seal my holy Christian faith.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.l: O noble sir Hugh, o lamentable hearing.

lg.l: Convey that other body hence, and give it
Burial as befits her state: for this, bestow
it on these shoemakers, as he bequeathed it.
No shoemakers now sir, but the gentle craft
Shall see it buried in state and pomp.
Use your own pleasures; where's Bassianus?
How chanced our daughter, bright Leodice,
Came not to see these slaughtered Christians?

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.p: She keeps her chamber sir.

lg.l: Is she not well? let her be kept with care,
And to the gods of Rome these trophies rear. Flourish, exit Maxim.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Well my masters, I could find in my heart to rail upon this emperor Mr. Minus, but that I doubt he'll make us all die like Christians, and that he shall never do as long as we live I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.p: We'll watch him for that i'faith.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: So let him pass then, and let us lay our sinodicall heads together, to know what shall become of sir Hugh.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.p: Let's all join together, and bury him.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: How like a christian thou talkest: what before he be cold? than we should use him as many rich heirs desire to use their fathers: no, because he was a prince, and did such honour to our trade, we'll bury him like a prince and a shoemaker.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Agreed, agreed.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: You know he gave us the name of the gentle craft, and if we should give him an ill word now, 'twere a shame i'faith.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.p: That's true; how shall we do then to honour him?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Marry thus fellow-gentlemen, of my fellow Hugh's making, to requite his kindness, because he died a christian, he shall no more be called sir Hugh, but st. Hugh, and the saint for ever of all the shoemakers in England.

lg.l: O brave, brave Barnaby: st. George for England,
And st. Hugh for the shoemakers.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: An you be gentlemen, hear me: you know besides, has given his bones amongst us. Now you must not think as if a butcher had given us a dozen of maribones to be picked.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Well, well, how then?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Marry thus; in memory of his gift, all our working-tools, from this time for ever, shall be called st. Hugh's bones.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Brave, brave, that shall stand for ever i'faith.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.p: Ay, but which of our tools shall we call so?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Marry even all fellow Raph, all the tools we work with: as for example, the drawer, dresser, wedges, heel-block, hand and thumb-leathers, shoe-thrids, pincers, pricking-awl, and a rubbing-stone, awl, steel, and tacks, shoe-hairs, and stirrups, whetstone, and stopping-stick, apron, and paring-knife, all these are sir Hugh's bones. Now sir, whatsoever he be, that is a gentleman of the gentle craft, and has not all these at his finger's ends, to reckon them up in rhyme, shall presently up with him, and strappado his bum.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: An everlasting law renowned Barnaby.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Nay, hear me sing like a swan, or a sowter: furthermore, if any journeyman shall travel without these tools, now called st. Hugh's bones, at his back, and cannot slash, cut, and crack coxcombs, with brave sword and buckler, long sword, and quarterstaff, sound a trumpet, or play o'th flute, 'Or bear his part in a three man's song, he shall forfeit a gallon of wine, and be counted a colt as long as his shoes are made of running leather: speak, is't agreed on?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Agreed, agreed, agreed.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: We'll take up the body then.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.p: I'll have a leg of him.
And I another.
And I another.
And ilo help thee Raph.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: With reverence and with silence then: for as we have made these laws in remembrance of him, so it shall not be a miss to make it the sweeter, to reckon up our tools, and put them in meeter, and instead of a dirge, I think it fit time and reason to reckon sir Hugh's bones in rhyme:

lg.l: The drawer first, and then the dresser,
Wedges and heel-blocks, greater and lesser;
Yet 'tis not worth two ganders feathers,
Unless you have the hand and thumb-leathers:
Then comes your short-heels, needle, and thimble,
With pincers and pricking awl, so neat and nimble:
Rubbing-stone next, with awl, steel, and tacks,
Which often will hold when the shoe-leather cracks:
then stirrup, stopping-stick, with good sow-haires,
Whetstone, and cutting-knife which sharply pares;
And lastly, to clap saint Hugh's bones in
An apron that's made of a jolly sheep's skin,
And thus to all shoemakers we bid adieu,
With triumph to bury the famous st. Hugh. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus Qvintus.
div.stage: A cry within, arm, arm, arm; then enter a sort of country people at several doors.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Arm, arm, arm; what shall we do neighbours?
The beacons are on fire, and my heart freezes in my belly.

lg.l: They are fired round about us, and all the country in an uproar;
My very nose drops with fear.
If our enemies find us in these cold sweats,
We are all sure to go to th' pot for't.
Therefore let's go to th' pot first;
For when the drink's in, the wit's out:
And when the wit is out, we shall fight like mad men.

sp.l: Content, and as we go, let's raise the country.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Arm, arm, arm.

div.stage: Enter Bassianus and latius.

lg.l: What alarum's this?
Why cry ye so like mad men?

sp.l: Because we have no weapons in our hands sir.

sp.speaker: Lut.
sp.l: Why are the beacons fired?

lg.l: We are all afraid to think on't;
They say the enemy is landed sir.
Stand you here like sheep,
When danger beats so rudely at your doors?
There let 'em beat, he shall not be let in for me.
The enemies are landed men, and therefore we'll go by water:
Come neighbours.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: Arm, arm, arm.

lg.l: The cry is still raised, let's put the court in arms,
And certify the emperor.
With all the speed that may be,
Arm, arm, armExeunt Bassian. And Lut.
Let us be wise neighbours,
And whilst they cry arms,Exeunt neighbours, the cry continued.
Let us cry legs, and trust unto our heels.

div.stage: Enter Crispine and Leodice.

lg.l: The stratagem takes rarely, come fair Leodice,
This tumult in the court gives means to fly.

sp.speaker: Leod.
sp.l: Thus folded in thine arms I wish to die.

lg.l: Talk not of death, live, and be blessed for ever,
No frown of fate two faithful hearts can fever. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: Arm, arm, arm.

div.stage: Enter emperor and lords with weapons drawn.

lg.l: My horse and armour villains:
High Jupiter protect us; what neglect is this,
The beacons fired, and a whole land asleep,
When foes come armed in thunder?
Guard the court, see to our daughter's safety,
I fear these sudden tumults have disturbed her. Enter shoemakers with staves.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Arm, arm, arm.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: An you be men, show yourselves so.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Why d'ye cry thus? say, whither run ye?

lg.l: Out of our wits I think sir;
The beacons all along the sea-coast burn most horribly.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: And what's the cause on't?

lg.l: Because they are a fire sir: ten thousand Kentish men
Which woeful tail's to tell, are knocked down like sheep sir:
The enemy is landed at Sandwich, set ashore at Dover,
And arrived at Rumny marsh: hark, I hear the drums already. A low march.
I am amazed, what drum is this?
Stand on your guard.
I would your guard were here for us to stand upon,
That we might reach the further: come, fear nothing sir;
Let your lords and you stand by, and see
How we shoemakers will thrash 'em.

div.stage: Enter Crispianus with drum and soldiers richly attired.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Health to the emperor from the Roman state.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: These are our Britain friends, new come from France.

lg.l: Whom at your landing saw you up in arms,
That fright the country thus?
None my good lord, not any;
From France and Dioclesian thus I bring
These Britain soldiers back triumphant home:
The black storm there is laid, and sure these fears
That bring these homebred terrors, all are false:
And as I guess, the firing of the beacons,
Was at the fight of Dioclesian's fleet,
That with himself now rides in Dover-rode,
And is by this on shore: and how in France the die of war hath run
His majesty in these imperial letters certifies.
Thanks for thy news,
We'll read them straight.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: By st. Hugh bones we were all afraid of our own shadows, we shall have no cussing now I see. Enter Lutius.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: What news brings Lutius?

lg.l: Comfort my lord, the error's found;
The sudden fire that kindled all this fear,
Is now quenched out; the cloud that threatened storms,
Is turned to drops of heat: some knavish fellow
Hard by the sea-coast set a tree on fire,
Which seen, men thought that Dover beacon flamed,
And so fired all the rest, and raised the alarum.
I am glad it is no worse; run Bassianus,
And sing this comfort to our daughter's ears,

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: I shall my lord. Exit Bas.

lg.l: These letters of your noble victories
Are as yourself most welcome, on whose head
Our brother Dioclesian lays the glory of the
Conquest o'er the Vandals and the Goths:
He writes, he gave unto thy manly thigh
The sword of knighthood, wishing us to add more
Honours on thee, which at his arrival,
His, and our hand shall do with royal bounty.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: I am your lowly vassal, royal sovereign,

lg.l: Dost hear fellow Ralph,
Methinks I should know this captain;
He looks as like Crispianus as can be?

div.stage: Enter Bassianus.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Now Bassianus, speak, how fares our daughter?

lg.l: Alas my lord, the court is all in mourning,
The Princess with this sudden fear
Is fled the court, not to be found by any.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Not to be found, why where's her nurse?

div.stage: Enter nurse.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: See here she comes.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Speak doting beldame; where's my daughter.

lg.l: Fie, fie, fie, I have not so much wit left
As to tell ye where I am myself, oh my side,
Pray let me breathe a little;
When this hurly-burly began i'th' court,
She ran, and I ran; she hailed, and I pulled;
She cried, and I roared; but her fear being
Stronger than my old bones, away whipped she
Out at the court-gates, and I fell in a found,
Stark dead i'faith; had not a gentleman usher
Come by and clapped me soundly, I'd been
Past telling tales by this time. O my back.
O dismal chance
Search every room; this dismal clamour
May so fear her blood, that death may
Seize her haste: if in the court you miss her;
See't proclaimed, that whosoever brings me
Her alive, goes laden with rewards;
If nobly born, we give her him to wife:
Make haste, slip not an hour,
While I set on to meet the emperor. Exit.
I say 'tis he; I'll speak to him whate'er come on't.
Crispianus?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: My honest fellow Barnaby!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: O rumps and kidneys, did not I tell you so?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.l: Honest Crispianus, welcome from France.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: I thank you: how does my master?

lg.l: In health, and brave as holly:
So art thou methinks .

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: The fortune of the wars: is my dame well too?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: The old wench still: she keeps the mark in her mouth

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: And how does my brother Crispin?

lg.l: O he is the foreman of the shop since you went
Nay, we have news to tell thee anon when we are
Drinking; we have given o'er the shoemaker's
Cloaks now, and are become gentlemen
Of the gentle craft, and all our working
Tools are called saint Hugh's bones.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: That's excellent.

div.stage: Enter shoemaker.

lg.l: How now my tall trencher men,
What make you amongst courtiers?
What my Mars, Bacchus, Apollo, virorum,
The Basseius manus, my noble Crispianus:
And how does the brave monsieurs in France,
My brave shevaleere? As I am a gentleman
Of the gentle craft, thou art welcome.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: I thank your love and kindness sir.

lg.l: Away my strong beer drinkers;
There's a noble in English, go drink a health
To saint Hugh's bones; I must have
Some speech in private, and enter parley
With my man of war.
As long as this drum will strike,
We'll fight it out with pike and pot:
We'll drink a health to you both master. Exit.
Away my fine leather sellers,
Shrink awhile i'th wetting; whilst thus
I salute my right worshipful cordwainer:
For I hear say the knightly dub-a-dub
Has been laid on thy shoulders.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: It pleased the emperor so to honour me.

lg.l: He honours me and all my company by it ;
By saint Hugh's bones thou shalt take the
Wall of thy master now i'faith boy.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: The wall, not so sir.

lg.l: And the kennel too by the spreech-awls
Nay sir, I know more than you think I do:
Your brother has song the three man's song,
And told all i'faith: you were
Once my princely prentice.
Sir if my brother has disclosed
To you our births, I do conjure you,
As my dearest friend, for to conceal it.
Mum, mum boys,
As close as my currier and I in a tavern
On a Monday morning: tut, my princely
Prentice, thy brother knows that I am leather
That will hold all waters when he trusts
Me with a secret: hark in thine ear boy,
Has got a wench with child byth' mass.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: How, a wench with child?

lg.l: Yes, and a great one too:
No less than the emperor's daughter,
and she's as big as she can tumble:
Has entered the best chamber ith' court,
Has tickled her shoe-sole for a girl or a boy
By this time; and hark once more,
She lies in at my house too, but mum; no more words boy.
Pray heaven you catch no hurt by it,
For the emperor sends forth wondrous search to find her.
No matter,
She shall be welcome home whene'er she comes,
I hope she's delivered too by this time,
For I heard such a caterwauling,
And my wife stirs up and down that she stinks:
Nay more, the beacons were fired on purpose
To steal her from court, and only
By the knavery and policy of
Gillian Ginger-taile my wife.
The accident is strange;
See, here comes my dame and brother.

div.stage: Enter Crispinus, and shoemaker's wife with a child.

lg.l: God's me she's delivered:
Ha boy, art come? come hither Crispin,
Know ye this shevaleere?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: My dearest brother.

lg.l: I am glad to see you:
I hear strange news brother.
If from my master sir the news did come,
'Tis true, and I'll with life maintain.
Look here old sis,
Your other prentice is come.

sp.speaker: Crispian.
sp.l: My gentle dame.

lg.l: Sweet Crispianus, welcome home from the wars;
Nay sir, your brother has been in arms too:
Do you you see what exploits has done?

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.l: Is't a boy wife?

lg.l: A boy I'm sure,
has a purse and two pence in't:
Nay come sir, you shall kiss your kinsman:
Here's his father's own nose i'faith.
A princely babe,
The eye of heaven look on thee,
And mayst thou spread like to the
Bay tree, which the whole year springs,
And through this land plant a whole race of Kings.
Nor shall he scorn,
Till that race be run,
To call himself a prince,
Yet a shoemaker's son.
Of the Britons' blood, royal i'faith boys:
Let no man therefore henceforth take it scorn,
To say a shoemaker's son was a prince born.
Good fate succeed it:
Brother my master hath told all your strange proceedings:
Have you heard of the proclamations?
Yes, and mean ere long
To use it for my profit.
Till when, muff this son
In some dark cloud, whilst I at court
Wait on the emperor, that's gone to
Meet great Dioclesian; fortune
May turn her wheel, and we
May stand as erst we did,
And with our own beams shine.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: Play you your game at court, the next tricks mine.

lg.l: And by saint Hugh,
Though I neither shuffle nor cut,
I'll hold cards too.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: And I'll not fit out, though I turn up noddy.

sp.speaker: Crispia.
sp.l: Work wisely then, and part.

lg.l: Do so till time ripen, which being known,
A shoemaker's subtle wit shall then be shown. Exeunt.

div.stage: Trumpets sound: enter Dioclesian, Maximinus, Bassianus, latius, with drum and colours.

lg.l: Great Dioclesian, our renowned brother,
In France your happy and triumphant deeds
We here in Britain thus congratulate:
The Vandal and the Goth we hear, have paid
The price at full for daring insolence.
Even with their bloods they have:
Their daring and their downfalls fill one grave,
And yet our conquest had not spread such wings
But for those Britain forces you sent o'er:
They from the French field plucked the noblest flower,
And of them all, a soldier too, whose fame
I cannot sing too much, carried the name
Of honour from us all: his good sword flew like lightning,
And where it went, o'erthrew: the King of Goths
Called me his prisoner, but then this brave opponent
Fetched me off in ransom with his blood, and that being done,
He like a lion on the Vandal run:
Took him, and closed the battle in his fall,
The work was bloody, rough, and tragical;
And therefore for my love pray crown his head
That twice saved mine: it is a man, whose fate
Upheld the glory of the Roman state.
The man you sent, and praise so royal sir,
Shall ever live within our princely favour;
One call the captain hither.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Here he comes. Enter Crispianus.

lg.l: Brave soldier, your high spoken merit
Breathed from an emperor's love, claims due regard
From his and our hands: cast therefore but your eye
On all the kingdom, what you can espy to please you,
Ask, and take it.
Which we'll confirm brave Crispianus,
Make thy princely boon worthy thy fame,
and such as may beseem great Maximinus and Dioclesian,
The masters of the triple world, to give,
And by our gods thou shalt the same receive.
I humbly thank my lords;
I'll ask no gold, nor lands, nor offices; but thus high,
To beg a prisoner's life and liberty.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: A prisoner noble sir, what is he?

lg.l: 'Tis a sad Queen, my mother royal sir,
Imprisoned by your grace at Rochester.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: King Allured's Queen thy mother?

lg.l: Yes my good lord, my kingly father slain,
I and my brother did disguised remain,
Till I was pressed for France.
This wonder doth amaze me:
Is Crispianus then a King's son found?
'Twas voiced abroad, thou and thy brother died in the battle.
Fame speaks not always troth: I live,
But of my brother what's become, as yet I have not heard.
Thou here shalt live right dear in our regard;
Lutius by this our signet free the Queen from prison,
And give her knowledge of her princely son:
Oh were our daughter found, so much I love thee,
Thou shouldst enjoy my bright Leodice.
We thank our brother's love to grace our friend,
For to his worth we can no gift extend.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: What shouts are these? Look out. A shout within: enter nurse.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Out of my way sir: o my heart!

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Why what's the matter?

lg.l: The matter say ye? pray let me gape a little;
I was out of my wits before with fear, and now for joy.
O my heart, I think in my conscience I have not so much wind left in my belly as will blow out a candle:
The Princess, the Princess sir.
Ha? my daughter?
Say, where is she?
O my sweet lambkin's found,
And come to court too.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Where? who found her?

lg.l: A pretty handsome stripling by my holidame;
Her own shoemaker belike, poor duckling:
She was wand'ring, and he met with her;
And belike she had worn out her shoes, and he fitted her finely:
So drew on her shoes first, and drew her to court after;
And he and all the company of the gentle craft sir,
Brings her home most sumptuously.
With music's sweetest strains conduct 'em in,
Our sorrows wither, as our joys begin.

div.stage: Music: enter shoemaker, and other in their liveries, then Leodice and wife with the child: Crispine bareheaded before, Barnaby and the rest after: Leodice kneels, and Maximinus embraceth her.

lg.l: Life cannot be more welcome; which is he
Doubles my joys in my Leodice?
This is the youth that doubles 'em:
Oh my sweet honey-suckle, have I found thee again?
I'll triple his rewards for finding her:
And to be sure my daughter, not to lose thee more,
Great emperor see
To do all honour unto this prince, and thee,
I give my only daughter for his wife.

sp.speaker: Leod.
sp.l: His wife my lord?

lg.l: By my daughter:
Though a stranger to thee, he's a prince born,
Son to a King, and well deserves thy love.
Here's one deserves it more, he saved my life
When I was almost dead with grief;
These can witness it.
'Tis very true sir; when she was the lost sheep,
He was the shepherd that found her;
When she was a cold, he covered her;
Nay more, when she was hungry, he filled her belly:

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.l: Here's one, if it could speak, would be a witness to that.

lg.l: And by the proclamation, yourself are bound
to let this young man marry me:
I'll swear I'll wed with none, except this shoemaker.
Sure her sudden fright hath made her mad:
Was she not frantic when thou foundst her first?
Nay, she's mad still; how dare you stand this scorn?
This is a prince, that but a beggar born.
A beggar? look on this babe:
'Tis his own; 'tis princely born,
And a shoemaker's son.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Fond girl.

lg.l: Good father hear,
You know not what brave men these shoemakers are.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: 'Tis known we can get children sir.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: How am I vexed with fools and mad men!

lg.l: I do beseech you sir, my royal father,
Take this lovely child to kiss, and bless it.
Defend me Jupiter, she's mad,
Stark mad.
Why does the fair Leodice
So vex her kingly father
With so base a brat?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: 'Zounds base?

lg.l: Peace knave, peace:
What wilt thou do?
Base brat?
Alas, had the poor fool a tongue or power to speak,
He'd swear you did him wrong:
By all our gods it is as nobly born
As the proudest here.
Strange frenzy,
Why does my daughter so dishonour me?
I take but this poor child's part, and so should you:
For look you father, this base brats mother
Lay in my mother's belly; were she alive,
She would acknowledge it, and comfort give,
And it shall call you grandsire if it live.
Here's strange and dark enigmas,
speak plain, whose child is't?

sp.speaker: Leod.
sp.l: This shoemakers.

lg.l: And yours?
'Slife he has lain with her,
She's his whore; attach the villain,
Tortures shall force his baseness to confess it.
Most royal sovereign,
Suffer not wrath to kindle in your bosom,
His baseness and mine run even in one stream:
It is my brother, princes by birth, the King of Britain's sons;
Our names Eldred and Offa; for these names
Of Crispin and Crispianus we but borrowed
To keep our lives in safety.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Can this be true?

lg.l: Father it is, and this long since I knew,
Loved, and then married, a twelvemonth since:
This token, could it speak, would tell you all.
Whom heaven would save from danger, never can fall.
My blessing compass both:
Nurse, what say you to this?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Nay, I was asleep when 'twas done i'faith.

sp.speaker: Diocl.
sp.l: She winked a purpose. Enter Queen.

sp.speaker: Lut.
sp.l: The Queen my lord.

lg.l: Most welcome, and most wished for,
Royal Princess, your fetters off,
Imprisonment we here take off,
Go, embrace your sons.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: O my dear sons!

lg.l: With them receive your daughter
To your love: wonders hath fallen
Since you have a prisoner been;
You, and your sons, and we are grown a kin.
Fame spread abroad the wonder,
And the fame of our dread lords the
Emperors, which in stead of death
Hath given an happy passage to our lives.
But royal sir, should I forget this shoemaker,
we break a bond, wherein we all stand bound:
My sons of you hath loving parents' found.
Faith madam,
I did the best I could for 'em:
I have seen one married to the emperor's daughter.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Would you had married me no worse.

lg.l: You all have done your best
To make our comforts full: for which we'll pay
Rewards to all, and crown this happy day.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: We have a boon my lord the emperor.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: What is't?

lg.l: That seeing these two princes,
Fellow servants with us, being of the gentle craft,
May have one holiday to ourselves.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: What month would you have it kept in?

lg.l: The five and twentieth of October,
That none of our trade may go to bed sober.
Take it:
These lines of fate thus in one circle met,
If Dioclesian please shall here close up.

sp.speaker: Dioc.
sp.l: In what circumference?

lg.l: Thus; 'tis more honour to make Kings,
Than be such: then let these twain,
Being English born, be Britain Kings again.
This in the North shall rule.
This in the South:
Brave Crispianus, to requite thy deed,
Great Dioclesian's hand shall crown thy head. A crown presented,
To Crispin this:
And this rich gift beside;
The fair Leodice to be his bride.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: I have an humble suit unto your highness.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: What is't my son?

lg.l: 'Tis this;
A church then, and a beauteous monastery
On Holmhurst-hill, where Albon lost his head,
Offa shall build; which I'll st. Albon's name,
in honour of our first English martyr's fame.
Build what religious monuments you please,
Be true to Rome, none shall disturb your peace.
Set forward princes, fortune's wheel turns round;
We kingdoms lose, you the same hour sit crowned.
And thus about the world she spreads her wings,
To ruin, of raise up the thrones of Kings.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
